Early Access Review
								In the modern world of gaming, a lot of venerated video game genres have died a slow death - most notably the 90s platformer.Another genre that suffered the same fate was the combat racer.And just like the 90s platformer, the combat racer has risen from the grave with GRIP.I did not grow up in the heyday of these games - I was four years old when Rollcage was released, and the most combat-est of a racing game I played was the PS2's Rumble Racing (which was amazing).For the longest time, I have been searching for a racing game that was not an uber-realism Gran Turismo wannabe, and here it is. It saddens me when I ask someone if they enjoy racing games, and they say 'no, I don't like Forza or Project CARS'. There is so much more to the genre than having the highest polycount vehicle model.This is a racing game for people who don't usually play racing games. It's easy to learn but difficult to master. You can play it for 10 minutes, or 100. It's versatile, loud, engaging, and strikes the perfect balance of inducing righteous fury at the guy who hit you with a missile while not making you so angry you quit the game.Most importantly - it's fun to lose.For myself, who grew up with Rumble Racing, Motorstorm, Test Drive: Eve of Destruction, and Jak X, I can immediately see that the developers care about what they are doing. The music is amazing, the environments are stunning, the motion blur is excellent, the particle effects are the right mix of sensibility and EXPLOSION. Each sound and visual is tailored so that you know exactly what is happening on screen. As your vehicle gets more damaged, your HUD begins to lose integrity in a fantastically thematic way. The vehicles feel meaty and weighty, and you rarely feel like a crash was the fault of the physics engine.EDIT: Okay, not rarely. Usually. The physics engine is the devs' current main focus, and while it's come a long way, your car will still do some wacky things on occasion.It is in early access, so there are bugs. There is an excellent forum for reporting, and bugs are constantly being fixed by the dev team.We need to prove to the world that games that aren't MOBAs, arena shooters, or freemium microtransaction stores can SUCCEED. Buy this game, and invest in both the future of the game industry and the future of your procrastination time simultaneously.

Early Access Review
 I've received a copy for reviewing, yet this hasn't affected my review.  It's finally here...The successor for the PlayStation and PC game, Rollcage, has arrived in full force! The current version gives us on the plate three game modes (Race, Arena, Playground), one car and plenty of stages for now. The single problem I had so far was the lack of control, steering of the car proved to be really difficult and I could not maintain my first place at all, I hope it is going to get fixed as soon as possible for a smoother gameplay, I pretty much felt like a newbie. It is one of the few cons I've found so far in the game, the rest of it is simply divine. Gameplay Going onto the game modes, race let us compete against computer controlled cars with some intense combat in the package, basically high speed chasing after the first place with miniguns and missiles. Sad thing is, there's only miniguns, two types of missiles and landmines so far and I'd love some more diversity in the weaponry, but it's early access so they'll probably develop some more in the meantime. While racing gives us a combat for the first place, arena is a merciless carnage where all drivers are put to fight against each other with the mentioned arsenal at disposition along with a speed boost and shield (They are also in the race mode, do not fret) powerup. Then, comes the playground mode where it pits the player to find all the 42 packages on a map that looks like a construction site but also gives us a few hints as of what destruction to expect later on (In the site map you can destroy walls, pillars) yet I ran into the problem that if you crash into certain places and get stuck you can't respawn but to exit and restart it from the start. Graphics The stages are pure eye candy, just stunning and extremely detailed even for the ones that are prototypes. They all have a different setting which makes them unique but, there's something that bugs me and those are the barricades in the tunnels which are really easy to hit and can make you fall down in the leaderboard to the last place quite fast. OST & SFX The soundtrack? Drum and bass is enough for an eargasm and some chills down the spine as you destroy your way to the first place! Should you buy it? Grip is already a masterpiece and has met my expectations. You should buy it as soon as possible, because this is a gem that shouldn't be missing from your game collection and its the best experience you can get for this price. Early Access Review
								GRIP is pretty cool!  We need more of these combat racers.  The graphics engine used is perfect, Unreal 4 does a great job here.  For an early-stage alpha, it shows great promise.The problem is that I think the controls are a little sluggish.  I can notice at least a 0.25s input lag on every turn of the joystick.  It made it difficult to play, to be honest.  I'm normally very good at racing games, but this game made me feel like I had never played a racer before.  Each time I had to avoid an object, it was like I pressed the controls too late.  Even on easy mode, with the rubberband "catch up" mode enabled, I can barely avoid make last place in a race.  It's actually almost impossible for me, and when I compare my reaction times with something face paced like Race The Sun, this game feels like there is an old grandma at the wheel.  PLEASE make the turning reaction quicker!  There are only a few modes right now; racing, arena, and playground.  Racing I found too difficult due to lag, and that leaves arena as a focus point.  Well, there are machine guns and rocket launchers.  It's very ordinary.  We need many, many more weapons to make it interesting.  But it's a good start.  Playground could be fun, but there's only one map right now, they should let us explore the racing maps and arena maps too.  In the one "construction" map, there is some fun to be had here, but a problem I had is that you cannot respawn.  If you get stuck, you need to exit and enter the map again.  There are 42 packages to find in the playground map, but you need to find them all before you get stuck somewhere, as every time you reload the map you need to start over.  Lame!  Let us just find all 42 packages once, or at least remember which ones we previously found, otherwise it's not an easter egg hunt anymore.  A fix for this would be to make the respawn button just respawn us at the beginning of the map.  Also, in playground mode there is some excellent examples of map destruction (walls to destroy, pillars) which I suppose are previews of what to expect later.  These are really cool.  But for some reason you can't play local co-op in playground mode.  This would have been the most fun!!!The map design for the races are done very well.  There are only a couple that do not have "VERY EARLY ALPHA PROTOTYPE" plastered all over the thumbnails, but to be honest they are all very good.  It was never the maps that threw me off, and they are all very unique and well though out.  Except that one where you go through tunnels and have to somehow fit in a pathway that is the width of the car.  Please remove or limit the size of these little barriers.  I have never been able to make it through that gap.  It's a problem.  Especially with how sluggish the controls are.So overall, the game is very hard to recommend.  However it IS an early access alpha, and it looks great.  It feels right, but not tight.  It's just in need of a few more maps and weapons before it's ready.  The hard part is done, now they just need to finish it.  I'm really looking forward to seeing patches for this game come rolling down the pipeline and to watch it progress.

Early Access Review
								This is a spiritual successor to the "Rollcage" series from the late 1990's/early 2000's, which means that if you liked Rollcage, you'll absolutely love this, and if you've never played Rollcage but like fast-paced combat racers focused on skill, you're at least certain to like this a lot. Think Trackmania mixed with Mariokart mixed with Rocket League, and you pretty much have this series of games, it's challenging, fun, addicting, and generally just really, really good. It's got online multiplayer planned, and unlike most other modern PC games, it also has splitscreen multiplayer available.I see that some people complain that the game's currently too hard, which is something I disagree with. Like most other racing games, the tracks themselves are bigger foes than your opponents. The difference being that this game, just like it's predecessors, kick this up a notch through a combination of neckbreaking speeds, tunnels, and obstacles that require skill, timing and precision to avoid in an efficient manner, but of course this becomes harder when the racers in front of you plant mines for you and the other competitors to hit, and the ones behind you fire various projectiles your way. It won't hold your hand, and nor should it. It'll be hard when you first start playing, sure, but this only ensures it being a satisfying experience once you've gained the skills required. I will admit that I find the game a bit too easy at the moment, if anything. In it's current state, the AI's pretty stupid and will do many mistakes, and the tracks themselves aren't particularly hard to master either (explained by the fact that only "Easy" and "Medium" difficulty tracks are currently available, with only one of the tracks being relatively finished). One thing to note however is that the controls currently in place adds some difficulty that wasn't present in the older games; the steering feels a bit clumsy and unresponsive, which is something I hope and think will get fixed fairly soon.  It's also got a really stable technical foundation, beautiful graphics, and great performance, I've tried it on different hardware ranging from a relatively "low-end" gaming system with an AMD A10 7850K coupled with an Nvidia GTX 560, and a "higher-mid-end" system with an Intel i5 4690K coupled with an Nvidia GTX 970, and it runs really well on both, with the latter system running it with max settings in 1920x1080 with ease, making it a gem compared to most other graphically advanced early access titles.The sound design is also really good, with satisfying 3D effects and feedback, albeit it's suffering from some glitches at the moment (certain explosions and bullet impacts sounding as if they're right next to you, even though they're happening at the other side of the track), but minor quirks like that are to be expected in such an early stage of development, and the developers are working on a fix. As long as you like Drum & Base, it's also got an absolutely killer soundtrack. The developers are perfect for this game, not only because some of them worked on the previous games, but also because they listen to and interact with the player base, not only on the Steam forums, but on their own forums as well, making sure reported problems get fixed, and popular suggestions get implemented.I think most of the success about this launch is thanks to the fact that these developers work out of passion. This whole thing started out of love for the original games, and even though their kickstarter campaign failed horribly due to a lack of attention, they still fought on and got it into a working state, as opposed to quite a lot of EA developers out to make a quick buck by catering to popular genres, and then more or less abandoning the project once a satisfiable amount of money has been made.Oh, and if everything goes according to plan, which I have no doubt it will, we will also get modding tools allowing players to create their own cars and tracks.So, TL;DR:+ Fun, addicting gameplay+ Splitscreen support+ Great sound design+ Amazing soundtrack (If you like DnB)+ The rare combination of good graphics and great performance+ Awesome developers that are actually passionate about their work and release good while listening to and interacting with the community (I.E how Early Access should work)+ IT'S ♥♥♥♥ING ROLLCAGE- The AI's currently a bit too easy/stupid- The steering's currently a bit unresponsive- Some minor glitches

There currently is only one proper vehicle (though in several color variations), there are not that many tracks yet, my controller doesn't work in the menus and it's a pain to change some settings like resolution. There are also some glitches and bugs I've experienced, plus the physics and collisions don't always feel on point. Yes, this is in Early Access and very much feels like it, so those of you who want an absolutely polished, content-rich game should probably wait out.Now on to the things GRIP has in store and already makes right - it is ridiculously fun and addictive! I never played the original Roll Cage, but I quickly fell in love with the concept. It's mad fun driving on the walls and on the ceiling and makes for a very dynamic gameplay. The controls, while a little tricky at first, feel tight. Just as tricky can be the car's behaviour on ramps and during landings playing it for the first time, but it's easy to get used to the physics. The sense of speed is in full effect, though it rarely feels like actually driving 400+ km/h ;) Still a fantastic feeling to drive past all opponents when the nitrous pickup kicks in! Speaking of pickups: The current selection of pickups offers the typical variants that I expect from such a car combat game. Nitrous, mines, shields, short-range miniguns as well as chasing rockets. Each pickup can help tremendously when used right, but also be wasted when the usage is timed badly. A great feature that compliments the pickup weapons well is the function to manually activate slow-motion. You can pull off very cinematic sequences with enemies losing control because of you shooting at him, causing him to drive up a rock, spinning uncontrollably in the air - all in awesome slo-mo! The game does a good job at presenting all the action that is caused by the sly tracks, by the use of pickups and by the AI drivers. I quite like all of the three AI presets that this game has to offer. But GRIP is tense even on the easiest difficulty, as a simple screwup or a well timed hit by an enemy in the last section of a track usually results in losing several spots.Let's talk about content, that is not too shabby considering the EA state. There are three game modes available that contain different maps and tracks. Race is my favorite and currently contains three tracks. Two of those are more or less finished as far as I can tell, with the third one being in an early work in progress state - still being lots of fun already though. Players have several options to setup the action on the tracks. Along with the difficulty setting there are options to disable pickups, to configure the number of laps (2,4 or 8) and the number of combatants (6,8 or 10). On top of that, the engine power can experimentally be raised and a catch-up assist can be enabled. I really like this option for a rubberbanding AI, as it can be easy to mess up and loose the opponents. This option helps catching up on the enemies to ensure a tense race. Arena has all the same options and sees all the combatants trying to damage and eventually frag each other. Once again, there are three levels ready, with one being an experimental early build. Both Arena and Race seem to ultimately get 12 tracks each, which I would be totally fine with. I'm having so much fun on every single one of the available maps that I'm sure that the others will be equally great. Next up is the mode Playground, that has the player collect some orbs spread across a huge, you guessed it, playground and just mess around with the vehicle and lots of ramps and walls. The devs apparently want this mode to have three playgrounds, with one already available. Greyed out for now is the Time Trial mode, which I guess will pretty much be Race without the opponents. Not there yet but hinted at already is "Grip League". As the devs want to add online functionality with a future update, I figure this will be a competititve online league. Lastly, there already is a splitscreen mode for two players in place with the same modes and options as in solo play, minus Playground. Great fun for some couch competitiveness, with four player splitscreen already announced as well. So all in all, I wouldn't call the content sparse, though it's also not packed with lots of vehicles and tracks...yet. The content as of today is solid for EA and there are many great things in prospect.The soundtrack consists of some great Drum'n'Bass tunes that fit amazingly well to the action and always get me pumped. Graphically, it looks pretty good. Even though the early version tracks might look a little barren, the game overall looks good in motion. I'd even call it pretty on the most barebone graphical settings. It has a decent amount of settings in this department, ranging from FXAA and TXAA as Anti-Aliasing solutions to object quality, effects, shadow, post process and texture quality settings. Playing on a R9 390, I5 6600K, 8GB RAM at 1440p, I use most settings at their highest choice and get a decent performance that sits well above 60 FPS for most of the time. I feel that the higher effects settings cost a lot of performance, so I leave that on Low and it still looks really good. Performance is pretty consistent, though the game might dip when lots of opponents are on screen next to explosions. With my slightly lowered settings, I keep the dips at a small pace though. Once again, considering the EA state, I'm impressed with both the looks and the performance.I absolutely love what I've played so far and immediately wanna get back into the combat madness! The main concept is brilliant and well executed. The content is okay-ish, with much more on the horizon though. There are some smaller issues that still scream "Early Access", but nothing that really comes in the way of having fun. If you are even slightly interested in what you are seeing and fine with content being gradually rolled out, go for it! Now! And thank me later :)

Early Access Review
								Though GRIP is now more than a year old, I can recall only the vaguest memory of it before its current multiplayer iteration. And that is a great shame, since it’s quite a remarkable game. This week it’s my favorite (non-pinball) game, and that’s even including some wonderful racing/driving games. But it’s not perfect...(For this review, I consider SINGLE-PLAYER only. At least for now.)GRIP, as the Store Page indicates, is a futuristic racing game, taking place on other planets with a varied selection of technologically advanced vehicles. What really makes these “cars” stand out….they can’t land wrong! (Other than backwards.) Because of design, whatever side they land on is the bottom, and they can instantly GO!!!...reaching speeds of about 600 MPH (1,000 KPH.) Of course, at those speeds, steering requires some substantial degree of precision, and even a small bump (or impact) can send a car HUNDREDS of feet into the air........!What makes GRIP special? You don’t have to be a great driver-gamer to have fun, or even to do well. While an experienced driver will certainly have an edge (especially with “newbie buttons” turned off), unlike most racing games, any player should outright WIN some percentage of races. And there’s even a “bail-out” button; holding the “respawn” button will get you back in the race with little time or distance lost, almost no matter the situation you may be in.GRIP is hard to explain. The vehicles basically “stick” to the track, so players will often find themselves traveling at high speeds……completely upside down. And that's often not obvious until something goes wrong, and gravity instantly takes control.The GRIP tracks are beautifully designed for functionality, as well as appearance. The Store Page trailers and screenshots say more than my words can begin to express (so I won’t try, except to say that what they add to the game can’t be measured.) Most tracks offer shortcuts that may offer an advantage….. if you dare! I expect to still be discovering new nooks and crannies for quite some time.The GRIP cars offer features very specific to players’ driving styles. Fortunately, I quickly found a car that suits beginning drivers (such as myself); slower, but with maximum control (and at average speeds of 250 – 300 MPH, good to have.) None of the cars are locked (and in fact, nothing in GRIP is locked at this point.) But none of the cars can be upgraded either. Yes, their color and rims can be changed (yawn), as can the tires. But does a tire change alter performance? Hard to say, and GRIP isn’t talking (that I could find.)The GRIP game modes are pretty standard. Simple racing (yet with weapons. Strange.....), battle racing, elimination racing and best time with one player only. For beginners, I’d strongly suggest the time trials. Being on the course alone is the best way to learn the tracks. (Although just being thrown unto an unknown track with nine other racers has a certain undeniable, desperate charm as well!) There are also two Deathmatch arenas and something referred to as “Carkour” that one presumes to be a form of car parkour. I have little experience with either.While GRIP’s best features speak for themselves (and LOUDLY so!), there are some less fortunate aspects that should be noted:While the tracks available are great, there aren’t very many of them, and almost half of them are simply reversals.Almost everything about each race is GREAT! But then what? There is no type of progression (at least for single player.) Presumably, much of the reason is that there are so many variables, possibilities and options, it would be difficult to create a standardized system of progression. Yet, it takes much out of the game (in this player’s opinion) to go nowhere. For example, currently in battle races, the final scoreboard has to wait for all racers to complete to finish calculating (even if you're last), which often never happens, no matter how long one waits. But the player soon realizes; So what if there’s no final score posted? It would serve no purpose in GRIP’s current form.Pickups are basically a “learn as you go” process, as well as studying the controller settings to try to understand how to use them. There’s nothing even remotely like a tutorial, and that would be VERY helpful (at least for beginners.) Which is a weapon? Which is a tool? What do the symbols mean? How do you use them?GRIP’s battle system is weak. Some weapons have little purpose, are badly utilized by the controller, and come with no explanation. (In fact, the only difference between the regular race and battle race is the final scoring method. This seems inexcusable.) The notification of points scored is almost meaningless. (Who did what, and to whom? Green text? Red text? Which name first…or second?)Personally, I find techno music lacks the sort of heart-pounding intensity I would choose for such immersive racing, but players have the option to race to their own music as well.The cameras can behave unpredictably, especially if you happen to get turned around, or are involved in a collision. And more camera choices really need to be considered.Best scores aren't stored. What's your best time on time trials? Your best Battle race score on a certain track? Once you leave that mode, it's gone forever.While GRIP has many changes to consider (some of which will be dealbreakers for many gamers), it’s still a fun game with lots of potential at a reasonable price. If these changes are made, this could be a top tier game. Otherwise, it’s still a fun game, just not with the power to keep most players’ attention for an extended period of time. (NOT written as a criticism, simply as an observation of a VERY competitive genre I've spent a respectable amount of time in.)Thank you.

								Grip is a very fast, futuristic combat racing game. With very nice looking graphics and nice soundtrack, the game can be an adrenaline rush. It’s a racing game where you can drive on walls and even the ceiling upside down. This takes racing to another level as you can use the terrain to your advantage. Combine that with weapons and power ups it’s a really nice game. It’s in early access at the moment so you can expect bugs and such.Graphics:The graphics looks absolutely gorgeous in this game. It runs on Unreal 4 engine so you can expect some nice graphics. The maps also look very themed, like the snowy track is dark and really feels like you’re racing in the snowy mountains. Plenty of option in the graphics menu as you can expect from any Unreal engine based game. I played the game on high settings (maximum is the EPIC setting.) and I was getting 40-60 FPS throughout.Sound:The music in this game is sort of a hybrid between techno and a little bit of metal thrown in. It’s very upbeat and fuels your adrenaline you get from the races. This sort of music is well suitable for a fast paced combat racing game. The good thing about music in this game is that you can individually select the tracks you like and turn the others off. There are a total of 10 tracks as of this review.Gameplay:At the moment you can only play 1 player or 2 player split screen. The split screen can be done horizontally or vertically. There is no campaign or multiplayer mode as of now but the developers are working on it. The car has huge wheels with the body in the middle so the wheels are sticking out on top and bottom, this means if the car even gets flipped upside down, you can keep going.There are many types of games you can play. Simple race, elimination, deathmatch, playground and time trial. All of these are pretty fun. Simple races are regular races where you have to complete a number of laps and whoever finishes first wins, if you get hit by enemy missiles or gun you will respawn. The Elimination is also like racing except when you eliminate someone they’re permanently out of the race. Deathmatch is a car arena where you have a certain number of combatants and you must go around collecting power-ups and trying to eliminate others. Last one standing wins the match. The playground is also arena with all sorts of tunnels, pipes, half-pipes and other obstacles and there are a certain number of collectibles you must pick up within the allotted time. The time trial is basically you trying to do the track in best time.You get pickups and you can hold 2 pickups at one time. The first one can be triggered using the shift while the second can be triggered by pressing the control key on the keyboard. These power ups include a machine gun, missiles and mines. There’s also the nitro boost speed power up and another protection power-up which sort of gives you armor at the back of your car so you can defend against machine gun or missiles attacks from behind. There’s a total of 2 racing tracks, 2 combat arenas and 1 playground map at the time of this review. The developers are working on more maps and more content. So keep an eye out for future updates which can make this game even better. A gameplay video of a race I did can be found below:

Having loads of fun with online MP!ROLLCAGE IS BACK!Copying my post from /r/grip:THE STATE OF THE GAME AS OF NOWHey guys,I suddenly stumbled upon Grip in the Steam store, and as an old Rollcage fan I was astounded. Is my childhood favourite making a return? YES! After watching videos and reading reviews I picked it up from Indiegala as they had a small sale.Even though it's early access and we all know how they usually go down in flames, this one has impressed me. I haven't had so much fun in a racing game in years. It's great! Really brings me back to the old Rollcage times, except Grip looks ASTONISHING and runs very, very smooth with my setup (i7-3770k&gtx970&144hz). There is quite a lot of content already, as there are several maps, cars and gamemodes available.So, after about 5 hours of gameplay I am putting together Pros and Cons, starting withPROS -Open and communicative devs E: Really, one of the developers played multiplayer with us!-Astounding graphics -Runs smooth, no lag or stutter -Basically Rollcage 2017 -The sense of speed is great -Driving is fun and rewarding -Gamepad support, later wheels -Physics work well for the cars that are ready E: New car is nice!-Several game modes included already -Interesting planets & fun tracks E: New "Hard" track is AMAZING!-Challenging AI (in races, not so much in Deathmatch) -Up to 10 AI in races is a plus -Some car customizing, more to come -A simple damage system already And the best for last..-PC SPLITSCREEN! At the moment for 2, later for 4! Whoooo!CONS -Splitscreen only functional with 2 gamepads at the moment! Keyboard+controller doesn't work yet -Soundtrack quite boring at the moment E: I have grown to like it, or just turn on spotify-Not so many weapons available yet -Online multiplayer isn't available anymore, coming back though E: It's back! SO MUCH FUN!-Story mode not available yet -Some gamemodes not available yet -Accelerating from a stop seems somewhy sluggish on all cars, but gets better after gaining speed. Not sure if intended. E: Physics improved, works again-Crashing to small obstacles and then just accelerating away is annoying. From 800kph to a small metal tube and poof, 0 kph. Maybe make a crash system instead of just stopping?-Cars should have some sort of spikes or something in the body to damage the car in the front and sides. Now it's just following and nudging a little. Maybe a part to purchase and customize? -Gravity seems too low sometimes, because if you bounce to the wrong direction from a rock or something, you are going to spend a lot of time in the air and land to the outskirts of the map, and resetting is always the best choice. -Not a ready game yet :[So there are my thoughts about the game for now. A really nice thing is that the devs are veterans and open to discussion in the forums and things get added and removed with the voice of the community in mind. It's great that they have a list on their website regarding what there is to come for the game. Looking forward to this game getting better and better, and I can already suggest trying the early access version. I am having fun with it!

								Aight so I know all the jokes surrounding games on Early Access, BUT MY GOD, if you ever were or still are a fan of combat racers, you ABSOLUTELY need to play and follow this game, cause it can bring the genre back into its former popularity. The game is only in pre-alpha (only 6 tracks currently, most of which are still under construction), but that alone is already more than just a proof of concept. The fun of GRIP is %50 competition, %50 sensory experience. I prefer to focus on the latter in this review, as I'm sure plenty others will make it a point to address performance/controls/UI (which aren't too shabby imo).So, GRIP manages to create that rush of high-octane chaos when you launch out of the finish line and you and the other racers are funneled into that first tunnel section; where the boys get sorted from the men. You truly feel the sense of speed as dilapidated sections of blast doors and support columns whip passed you. You feel the weight of your tremendous battle wagon, HAULIN' it down the track. Portable DescriptionGRIP is a battle racing game with a style reminiscent of similar combat racers released near the turn of the century, most notably Rollcage. With beautiful visuals and a heart-pumping soundtrack, GRIP is a fantastic way to release any pent up destructive tendencies. Note: GRIP is still in Early Access. There is currently no online multiplayer or campaign mode as of yet, but the game is still extremely promising. GameplayGame ModesGRIP can be played either solo, or with a local coop buddy. There is currently no multiplayer/campaign yet. To start a match, you must first choose a game mode, then a planet and track/arena. There are 8 different maps, some are WIP, available for play at the moment with a few tracks that are mode-exclusive. Each game mode can be customized by changing various settings, such as: No. of laps/combatants, difficulty, reversed/mirrored tracks, etc. The included game modes are:RacesEliminationDeathmatchPlaygroundTime TrialItem PickupsPickup platforms are placed throughout the levels which provide the player with weapons or powerups, such as:Raptor: high-impact machine gun.Scorpion: homing missile that targets the opponent in front of you.Assassin: tracking missile that targets the current opponent in 1st place.Quaker: proximity mine.Aegis: rear-facing shield.Firestorm: turbo-boost.EMP: EMP that shuts down opponents' engines. Video Gameplay (15 min)


YouTube™ Video: A Look Inside... - GRIP 

			Views: 37		

			If you're interested in seeing more sneak peeks of new indie games, along with walkthroughs and much, much more, subscribe to this channel!		

 ControlsHandlingGRIP's vehicular handling is not as tight as a kart racer, nor is it as realistic as a racing sim (for obvious reasons). The cars seem to be designed to go airborne, careen out of control or switch perspectives very often as you are essentially controlling an RC flip car. Although the handling is perfectly acceptable if these are the design intentions, controlling the cars are not as fluid as I had hoped. The developers are aware of this and the collision physics are a WIP. A couple suggestions that may help improve handling experience are listed below, however, I understand it may be very difficult to actually incorporate them. Increasing the vehicle’s weight, or sense of one. Reducing the reliance of releasing the accelerator to improve control; allow for strict handbrake control at full acceleration.PresentationArt & Sound DesignGRIP's visuals are truly magnificent. The tracks are extremely varied from each other with regards to level design, aesthetics, and environments. The different biomes you can race or battle through can be extremely luscious, barren or frigid; however, what remains the same is that the graphics are so good that they can sometimes distract you from the main objective. The accompanying EDM and fast-tempo soundtrack also does a fantastic job keeping you focused and immersed while providing a sense of speed and adrenaline rush.ConclusionEarly AccessFor those that are not aware of the Early Access concept, it is perfectly acceptable for bugs to be present (only minor ones observed) and game mechanics to be missing. According to the Early Access notes:The full version of GRIP will have 12 cars (3 classes), 16 tracks (4 planets), 10 pickups, career mode, arcade mode, arena mode (with arenas), precision mode (with a few tracks), multiplayer (online or local LAN and split-screen), mod tools for custom cars, and (depending on funding moving forward) a track editor so players can build their own courses. Our goal is to have the "final" version of GRIP by the end of 2016, though with the right support GRIP will never be final, as we hope to be adding new cars, tracks and possibly pick-ups well into 2017. The developers have shown interest in maintaining GRIP’s balance and development progression as seen in the major monthly patch notes here, and active responses in the Discussions board.VerdictGRIP is an extremely promising, albeit limited-content, combat racer/arena battler. With its impressive visuals, level design and combat mechanics, I can easily recommend this game to battle racing/arena fans; however, it is understandable to want to wait until the game releases career/multiplayer modes (local coop is already supported). For those that pick-up the game right now, understand that you have the power to help guide the developers with their balancing tweaks and feedback suggestions. They are very receptive and seem to incorporate player responses fairly well. Review copy provided by Caged Element Inc.

Early Access Review
It's a modern take on a crazy old school racer.Let's make one thing straight from the start. It's not Rollcage 3. It's a lot more than that :DEven at an early access state (highly pre-alpha), the game runs solid like stone. Even with the horrendous streak that nVidia has with their drivers, this game is yet to crash a single time for me. On top of that it runs smooth and utilises my favourite form of anti-aliasing, the TXAA. Optimisation is great and the Unreal Engine 4 powering this game seems like a magnificent choice given that the game graphical wise looks amazing retaining that Rollcage feel to it.Technical stuff aside, the gameplay is highly reminiscent of... yet again, Rollcage series. It's a spiritual successor after all, made by people who were also a part of the team that was responsible for the Rollcage series. You have an actual wallriding, not wall-welding known from Need For Sales, ceiling riding as well, a selection of weapons that that allow you to give out tickets to the moon in a disturbingly fast pace and even a pure deathmatch mode aka destruction derby, just with more... weapons and explosions. That said, if you don't like weapons, you can disable them and stick to pure racing.Early Access experience is... quite different. I've been a part of DiRT Rally Early Access which has an opinion of being one of the best so far on Steam ever, but let me tell you... those guys here are something else. They really take their time to post on the forums trying to explain the issues, inform and (here's the part that is just unbelievable) apologise for any and all breaks and lacks of activity that may occur.Aside from having great communication and actually implementing ideas and fixes (I mentioned a fix for a part of track, few days later it was implemented) they share their views and often discuss some of the more interesting topics. They're not afraid to ask for feedback on the forums but also can straight out say "we won't do it", which shows they have a vision for the game and don't want to just put everything there is into the game, which would most likely create a boring mess.Quite honestly, those guys put DiRT Rally early access to a shame. And that says a lot.Given that the game is still in Early Access, there's not that much content. Dev team is small (only one person responsible for entirety of physics!) so they're unable to pomp out a lot of content, however it's coming and nothing is being missed. If they say something is coming, then it is. Multiplayer is next, so... :DIf you're one of those that understand that realism can only be fully applied to things of past and present and not future (thus the term "futuristic" exist) and love some good ol' proper arcade racer, then this game is for you.TL;DR;- spiritual successor to Rollcage series, but gives option to not use weapons- technical side of the game is impeccable- puts DiRT Rally early access to a shame- content comes out irregularly but solidly, nothing gets missed

Note: I am completely aware that this game is an early access title, therefore the review will be built a little differently. But I will not hold back on any criticism that I might have. I will update this review as new updates arrive (Review was last updated on the 19th of April, 2017)GRIP is a spiritual successor to Rollcage/Rollcage 2, with polished graphics and physics.Gameplay» Driving physicsThe driving physics are a serious step up compared to the Rollcage-titles. However, I think the vehicles could use a little more grip on dirt-services, and a little less on asphalt. Perhaps a kind of drift-system would also be nice, because steering as of now kind of feels a little strange.» TracksThe race tracks all have a good amount of curves and straights, however, compared to the Rollcage titles, they are way less unique and varied. As of now, all the planets might as well be called: Desert rock planet, grass rock planet and snow rock planet.  There are no residential buildings to speak of and all the tracks feel dead. No beaches, no towns, just.. Rock. None of the planets are very memorable. I hope more unique track-designs and planets will pop up later in development.Also, there are random obstacles on some of the tracks, which are not destroyable. Those are really annoying and hard to dodge and can ruin the flow of the game.Speaking of destruction: As of now, the game is really missing out on that. The most destruction I ever saw were some knocked around barrels, that's pretty much it.Furthermore, the mirrored mode is very appreciated, you don't see that in many newer titles.» VehiclesThere are a bunch of vehicles to choose from with different stats. They are all modifyable with different colors, wheels and tyres. All vehicles look pretty unique, a very good step up from the Rollcage series.Misc» SplitscreenTHIS GAME HAS A SPLITSCREEN MODE. More games need this.» SoundtrackThe soundtrack, in my opinion, is taking itself a little too serious. While in Rollcage you had a couple of more light-hearted tracks, in this one they are just serious and a little boring. It's just the typical drum and bass sound that everyone knows nowadays, and I think none of the music-tracks are really memorable. They just lack melody, in a way.That is what I kind of noticed in general, the game takes itself a little too serious. No more beautiful looking beach-tracks with the right music to go along with it. I was kind of disappointed in that regard. Although the performance is a little lacking on higher resolutions/settings and the framerate likes to drop a little sometimes (Playing this at 4k on a 980ti felt kinda sluggish).» SettingsThe game has tons of settings. The only thing that is missing is a master-volume slider, that would be greatVerdictThis game is not a bad racer at all. It feels fast, and it's difficult. Early Access Review
								GRIP is a super speed racing game in the spirit of the Rollcage games (and the devs of it).Although the game is in early access, it feels very good gameplay-wise. Driving at 500 km/h (or up to 700 km/h!) feels awesome. Controlling the car properly gives enormous satisfaction. When you nail that curve, coming at it 500 km/h, ease off the gas a little to gain better control, dodge that mine in last second only to see that the guy coming behind you hits it, it feels pretty awesome. Or when you see and hear the guy behind you starts his gattler at you, you deploy your back shield to show a middle finger at him, then drop a mine in a tight tunnel and look back as your enemy drives right into it, exploding (then you drive against a wall because of looking back but that is beside the point).GRIP feels very good. This feeling comes from great soundtrack, gorgeous looking tracks and ofc the racing itself. Sound effects are top notch, for example everytime you fire the gattling gun it feels like it has some serious power. The low "chuckchuckchuck" sound of the gun, the swirling sound of the gattler "swrrrrrr", and the sound when it hits your metal enemy "chingchingching". You send your enemy veering and take the leader position. Soon after that you hear a beeb thats increasing its frequency, and realize a missile is coming to you! Quickly, you manouver to a power up hoping it would give you a shield. No shield? Tough luck. You look back and see a guy coming right after you. You let off the gas and brake just a little, to give that guy the first place. Soon after that the missile hits the guy infront (BOOM) of you sending him flying wildly all over the place, and you take the leader position again. All this while the crunchy drum and bass music plays in the backround to raise your pulse just the right amount. The driving itself is great. At first it feels like the car bounces too easily off the little bumbs etc, but you soon learn the use of braking and letting off the gas pedal dramatically increases your control. For example, you see ahead a little hill that you are going to take air from. If you go to that jump with full throttle and you are not driving 100% straight to it, you are gonna bounce wildly all over. Instead, you must ease off the gas a little, and make a little correctional driving manouvers so that you jump so that your car doesn't go all over but instead does a neat little controlled jump. Remember that you are driving 500 km/h, at that speed a little bumb or hill must be taken seriously. This makes the driving feel really good, you feel like you are in total control of your car, and if you get distracted you will be punished for that. It feels like you are on the edge all the time, even a small mistake can make you fly and spin. You cannot go full throttle and hit the walls in curves, like in some arcade racing games. Even if the game is really awesome, early access means very limited content though. Patches have been regular. I will remind you, dear reader, that if you want a full game experience with proper amount of content, wait longer. If, however, you can't wait to give these metal beast a run, enjoy awesome drum and bass music and wish to support this badass racing game, buy it now! Remember that buying the game now secures that it will come a finished product, and it already offers many hours of crazy speed driving goodness. I normally feel very sceptical about EA games, but this one I had to give a go and I am super glad I did!

Early Access Review
								A very fun, very intense, very fast futuristic racing game which is naturally lacking content due to it's early access.Gameplay: Racing is very satifying, but can sometimes be frustrating. The game harnesses super high speeds, resulting in very intense, fast moving action. You can find yourself being flung into the sky at points simply because you were going at speeds around 600 KMH, but this is not an issue in the more complete maps. Do not let the speed be a turn off for you however, as I would say its one of the most captivating mechanics of GRIP for good reason. To feel competitive in a race with such tremendous speeds around you, in such a way that your vehicle can drive smoothly up walls, is a feature found few and far in racing games, probably because its hard to utilise as a fun aspect of a race. GRIP executes this well with their tracks being built around many optional roads, shortcuts and large, curved terrain. This gives nice replayability with driving the race tracks, and can put forward different play styles as you go.Graphics: The graphics in GRIP are probably some of the best graphics I have seen of any racing game, to date. I have Play quite a few racing games over some time, and GRIP has captured almost perfect graphical immersion. From the textures on the car, to the back ground of race tracks, to the beautiful looking transparent shields, GRIP has shown no remorse towards a graphical component. When it comes to immersion, the game will produce a flame like HUD around your screen when you are hitting high speeds as well as a dust effect, having dots splinter your camera. You also see the physical gears of your rough gutted car switch as you gain speed. This game looks beautiful.Content: Of course, GRIP actually doesnt have a supreme amount of game to play currently as it is in early access. You will find yourself bored and wanting more within 5 hours of play time. As sad of a fact as this is, the developers are not weak with updates, most having content around 1.5 GBs, so you will always have something to toy around with on new updates. However as it stands now, you will run out of things to do quite quickly.I reccomend it. I encourage that you dont fear a lack of content, as it is dispensed some what consistantly. This game has mega potential, as I am sure you will feel when you try it for the first time.

Early Access Review
								Review and Bug Report – Developers, this is for you.  3 weeks into early access and I’ve picked up this game, played it for over an hour, and I’m gonna start off this review by saying that this isn’t simply a spiritual successor to the Rollcage series. It IS Rollcage 3, whether you want to call it that or not.Now, let’s get into the actual review. This is based off of playing Time Attack for almost the whole time, and should be treated as such. The sense of speed is exhilarating. I never expected to come into it and do well, and I didn’t; the case was the same with the first two games. I crashed a ton of times on every lap, span off or did a 180, drove up the side of walls, left the track boundaries, always struggling to get back on track, and losing a lot of time in the process. But it never feels cheap, nor is it frustrating. When you do screw up, you always know that it’s because that you just couldn’t quite handle the beast that is your vehicle, and that’s great, because Grip – and Rollcage as a whole – is not an easy game/series by any means – this game is hard. It takes a lot of precision and skill to master handling this four wheeled juggernaut; the smallest mistake can screw you over, but it really is rewarding when you can get it under control. And even if you do crash, drive off or spin off a bunch of times, the game never stops being fun as hell to play. ***BUG REPORTING STARTS HERE***Now let’s get onto the bug reporting. As it’s only 3 weeks into early access, I can forgive the fact that the UI and everything except the core game needs a huge amount of work. Still, it needs to be addressed:Screen resolution options: The resolution sets itself every time I click the arrow to go through the available screen resolution settings. So when I go from 1280x720 to 1280x768, screen flashes to black and then sets to the new res. And this happens for as many different available settings there are: the screen flashes to black no more than a dozen times before I can reach 1080p. We need to be able to click through them all without it auto applying every time: give us an ‘Apply’ button or a dropdown menu, the current system is far too slow. Second issue – the res resets itself from 1080p (my selected res) to 720p when I alt tab out and back in, and to make matters worse, there’s no ‘Options’ menu in the Pause menu. So all that time spent clicking through every available resolution to get to the one I need, down the drain. After that I just left it at 720p out of frustration.The menus can’t be navigated without a mouse – not even the Pause menu. I don’t think the keyboard can be used either. So I can pause the game with my controller (for reference it’s an Xbone controller), but to resume I need the mouse, which requires me to get into an awkward position so that I can left click resume with my left hand while keeping my finger down on the right trigger to accelerate. That’s the next issue – upon resuming the game at the Pause menu while holding down the right trigger, it does nothing: I have to release it and press it again to accelerate. For some reason I can pause the game after I finish the race and viewing my ‘You placed 1st!’ (Hahaha, me, first…) – This should not be possible. Nor should I be able to pause the game at this point.Please auto-hide the cursor during gameplay, or when a controller is in use.The hit boxes for the menu buttons are too small to be clicked with a mouse: the hit boxes should be the same size as the menu buttons themselves. 								Warning: This game is still in development! Having that said, this game proves 2 things.1: Arcade racing is far from dead. 2: '90s/ '00s gameplay still has a reason for existing today. I will explain these points. This game is based on a late PSX arcade racer called Rollcage. It was a futuristic racer like Wipeout and F-zero, with speed and course layout were the primary focus of the game. As with wipeout, Rollcage had weapons, which (if used correctly) could give you an edge or help you get back in the race. But most of all it was the rush of combining the speed, chaos and great music that made the game great.GRIP doesn't do much different than Rollcage did in it's days. It's still amazingly fast, it's tracks are still build to give you that awesome rollercoaster feeling and the music still completes the experience. But it only adds to that old Rollcage game with everything we like from our games these days, without taking anything away. The graphics are great, the tracks look magnificent, with my avagage PC setup the game moves at a steady 60 fps, weapons look awesome and work like a charm the 6 cars (which differ more than enough) sound great with each car another engine sound,. Talking about sound, there is so much quality and detail in that department here. We got the different engine sounds per car, the speed boosts sound powerful, you can hear the drivetrain sqeak at high speeds, missiles and machineguns sound great and the music completes it. You can do some basic car customisation by choosing the color of your car's paintwork, changing the rims and their paintjob and change which kind of tires you want on the car (although it doesn't change how the car handles). Then there are quite a few tracks and game modus (including a new online multiplayer) added to the game allready, but more will come. Tracks can be rough, which might make your car bump out of bounds, but resetting your car to the track is both easy and looks awesome too. The best thing is: the action and fun is so good, that it doesn't matter if you get 1st or last. It brings a smile to your face and before you know it, you are in another race, having the time of you life boosting through upsidedown tunnels, blasting other cars away, dodging obstacles and enjoying the immense sense of speed this game gives you. Rollcage is back, better than ever and now for the new generation to enjoy :D

Early Access Review
								First of all, let me say this... I'm very sceptical if it's about Early Access games. Those "games" often tend to be scams just to rip You off. However, that's not the case for GRIP. This game, for me, is a proof that there are studios out there that genuinely care about their projects and their fanbase. Caged Element are the good guys. Why You ask? I had this game on my radar for a long time, since I saw the first trailer, and the devs are constantly adding new stuff to the game, fixing bugs and tweaking the mechanics etc. This game is evolving, it keeps getting better and better. It traveled a long way since it's first versions.I won't be comparing this game to it's predecessor Rollcage. I'll focus entirely on my feelings while playing, without any nostalgia involved. Also keep in mind GRIP is constantly growing so my "review" can become out of date. I will update it i there will be a need for it.So... GRIP is an amazing combat racer, with exciting gameplay and amazing audio-visuals. It's fast, it's aggresive, sense of speed on highest engine power is face-melting, and to top it off, its Drum & Bass soundtrack is a cherry on the cake, it will make Your blood boil if that's the type of music You dig. And even if You don't, there is always the option to throw Your own music to the playlist but to be honest I didn't test this feature well enough because I thought it's unnecessary, for me, the original soundtrack is perfect.Gameplay itself feels demanding at first. Getting used to the vehicles take a little bit of time since it's not the type of racer where You can just hold the accelerate button to win, You must actually tame Your vehicle to have a chance of winning, they are designed in a way to allow driving on the walls and ceiling and it takes some practice and track knowledge. Every vehicle has different statistics, and even though the differences are subtle, they have a big impact on Your driving, You have to match the car to Your driving preference. For example, there is Cygon Ictus that is very agile but it can only take a few rockets on its face to blow up. On the other hand there is Vintek Juggernaut that is a typical tank and it can take much more hits but its handling is worse. And there are some cars in the middle also. Currenly there are more middle weight and tanks class in the game and only one speedster but it's going to change with the upcoming update.Now, the tracks themselves. They are classified in three categories, easy, normal and hard, and some of them are insanely hard. There are a total amount of 7 tracks right now and some of them comes with their reversed versions. Some of them are taking place on the ground and some of them are taking place high in the sky in a form of roads suspended in the air, and those are among the hardest. Environments are interesting, good looking, pleasant for the eyes. Even though there are not much tracks at the moment, there are options to stop You from being bored. For example, You can mirror every track so it can have a slightly different feel, so if You choose to race on a reversed and mirrored, it feels like You're racing on a completely different track. You can change vehicle destruction, number of contestants, number of loops and turn on/off the upgrades appearing on the road.Is there only racing mode? No. There is Classic Racing where only Your position matters. There is a Ultimate Racing where You gather points by being first and by using Your weaponry on the opponents. There is the Eliminator where every last car explodes every 30 seconds and it goes until one car survives (it's hard as hell btw) and there is my favourite mode which is Time Attack where You race alone infinitely just to improve Your track time. I tend to spend most time on Ultimate and Time Attack. There are also three arenas where there is no racing involved at all. You just have to kill Your opponents with rockets and mines. That mode took me by surprise, I didn't think I would like it, even though it's simple it is still a fun mode....but is there something wrong about GRIP? It's pretty impossible to create flawless game and GRIP is no exception. There are occasional issues with collision boxes where You can bounce unexpectedly or get stuck. It happens more often at breakneck speeds but even then it's rare. Also, You have to be careful where and when You shoot Your rockets because if used in the wrong place and time the rocket can slam back at You immediately after deploying. As far as I know it's the issue the devs are currently fixing.There is also another mode in which I've put the most hope but it turned out to be the most boring one by far. I'm speaking about the Playground mode. It was created due to people demand (I'm not going to hide, I was one of those people), it resembles the Scramble mode from Rollcage where You test Your driving skills on a very demanding short tracks. For some reason, this mode feels simply uninteresting. It feels like it was added as a bonus, like it's a very unpolished DLC or something. I have two predictions about this mode, either it will be improved last after tweaking the core mechanics of the game... or it will be obsolete and deleted in the future patch. Time will tell.Well... I wrote an essay didn't I? Long story short... I love this game and I can't wait how it will evolve in recent months, or even years. GRIP can be the best futuristic racer of 2017 if Caged Element will still work on it at their current pace.

								The asking price may be a bit high for a game thats still in development, but after getting in a solid hour of gameplay and racing multiple tracks several times i can honestly say that i havent played a racing game this fun in a long time.This game plays somewhat like a Mariocart game or the game Blur for the playstation referring the pickups you get during racing.  There's even a missile with a blue smoke trail that goes for the guy in first reminicent of the blue shell from Mariocart, which is always a good laugh (unless you're in first).  The car choice is very limited with mulitple colorations for the 2 choices, but this isnt really a bad thing.  The tracks are mostly well designed and thought out quite nicely.  The scenery of each track is great to look at too, especailly when you crash into something and come to a dead stop (then you can really enjoy the view!).  The controls for the game, overall, are very responsive which is great.  However, there are times where, when your car catches air, the vehicle controls about as well as a paper plate with a radio transmitter on it with you telling it through a microphone to turn left or right depending on where the track goes. This can be frustrating mainly due to the fact that you can throw yourself off the track by mistake, ruining the great positioning you achieved.  Now, this isnt game breaking by any means, but its still quite the annoyance when your car bumbs into a rock going 300 mph which sends your car tumbling and skipping along the track every which-way making it all the more difficult to regain control and get your car moving in the right direction again.  But getting a better feel for how the tracks are and how your car handles on them can compensate for this later on.The A.I. is also good.  They are about as competent as you are on the track and can mess up the same as a normal player would.  If the A.I. becomes too challenging for you, there are adjustments in the game that makes it so the computer wont completely leave you behind, giving you a chance to catch up.There are a few things still needing improvements on, but the developers are excellent in recognizing potential problems and correcting them.  They are deligent in keeping their game as balanced yet fun as possible.Overall, if you have 15 bucks to spare and are in the mood for EXTREMELY fast paced racing, i highly recomend this game. 9/10

								Graphics are great and I love the soundtrack but the gameplay is missing some very basic details.CONTROLS:Every time you hit a small pebble, your car will go into a frenzy of doing endless flips and you have no control over where or how it lands. The game does tell you there is a "air-control" mechanic, when you let go of the gas, but this to my experience does not work. At all. LEVELS:The level design only makes this matter worse, since there are all sort of small humps and bumps(also some loose barrels in certain maps) EVERYWHERE, and the instant you hit one of them it's very likely game over.WEAPONS:The weapons are missing a very important function aswell: SENSE. Two types of missiles: Scorpion(guided homing) and Assassin(1st pos). Both of these missiles seem balanced and pretty well designed.. One tenth of a time. More often than not, I find myself launching either of these missiles and having it explode into a wall right next to me, sending my car again into a death roll 360. When they dont hit the wall, they do work as intended though.The machinegun is just completely useless against human players, since they know how to compansate for the swaying of the car.The mines are pretty nifty and you can nicely block some quicker routes with them to eliminate competition catching up too quickly. I dont know if it's by design though that if you just happen to be driving fast enough over them, they wont blow up. This renders them almost useless, since in most maps you will be under the effect of a boost of some form for 80% of the time.EMP is great, but I think it should not last as long as it does. With the lenght of it now it completely manages to kill your speed and (although it does this to everyone else, let for the one that activated it) sits you still. This combined with the 360 noscopes your car will have been most likely doing just before and you can quit out of the game already. You have no chance to win anymore.END:I do recognize that this is a Early Access title(and with a fair price tag too!), but I simply cannot recommend this to anyone seeking an action racing game. Even though the market on the PC is still very scarce, that should not be an excuse for lazy game design. You're most likely better off getting Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed.Overall, I do like the more "adult" feel of the graphics, and the DnB soundtrack hits very close to home. The game functions(even though it crashed once for me during online play), but is still in search of tuning for the gameplay.

								"Roads...? Where were going we don't need 'roads' " A great futuristic racer with all of the familiar "tropes" from what made the original inspiring series so awesome. TLDR: Worth Buying! Great graphics, sweet electronic tunes and fluid controls.Sleek design, a unique mechanic of driving on any surface at high speeds, and the unbridled speed and chaos of launching yourself at high velocity into a wall only to barrel off and continue blazing along down the track. This stays true to its source material by including a great soundtrack with heavy electronic tunes that blast along as you continue down the track. Some cool weapon pickups (I wish the warphole weapon of the original were here still!) and great track design.If you remember the PS1 era futuristic racer (Rollcage) this has all the original trappings of that great series and more, presented with a stylish visual update. If you're a fan of futuristic racing games or racing games in general it deserves a playthrough especially if you have never experienced the series before. As far as future content goes, the tracklist is very limited as of 07/22/16 at  there are only 4 tracks and no League Mode as of yet. It appears the developers intend to include at least league mode. Hopefully some tracks similar to the levels in the original i.e. a downtown metropolis / futuristic city, a coastal area with building struts you can take out to take down buildings, a lava level, etc... Would be great to see! What matters is what content that is presented is very well done. I almost feel I could do without the playground, deathmatch, and elimination modes in favor of a more robust league / cup tournament mode and more levels. If you're a fan of the old series Rollcage it's a no-brainer purchase. If you're a fan of racing games otherwise, it's worth experiencing. If you're a fan of electronic tunes and futuristic stuff / cart esque racers with weapon pickups, you'll probably dig it. This is the best futuristic racer available on Steam as of 2016, hands-down. A great addition to a great franchise.

								GRIP, a game that is aiming to return to the unique style of car combat racing games that were Rollcage & Rollcage 2. This game is indeed a very worthy spiritual successor to Rollcage & Rollcage 2. I cannot reccomend it enough to anyone who enjoyed those games, or who enjoy a tough, yet very rewarding combat racing game. Definetly worth the asking price.

Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS EDIT (23rd June 2016):As of the latest patch, the handling feels much more interesting than it did. It's excellent with a controller, and alright with a keyboard - but I strongly recommend playing with a controller.I miss the older, lighter, more chaotic handling. However, as it currently stands, there's the potential for a game that's not just a curiosity or a fun pick-up game, but a classic. A few minor annoyances such as snags on invisible parts of the map and what feel like overly-harsh collisions with the force-fields that now form the map boundaries need to be ironed out.The game would also benefit from some more finished and polished levels that make the *absolute* most of the fun and exciting toolset they've got. The Hard levels they have are great, but some Easy levels that really flow (almost like a good Sonic level, with setpieces and the opportunity to really open up the accelerator) would really help to 'sell' the game to new players.EARLY ACCESS EDIT (11th February 2016):As of the latest patch, the nature of the game has changed a little, compared with my initial review. Cars no longer feel like RCs and in general feel weightier and less flighty. It's still fun, but it's less radically old-school than it used to be. With the difficulty as it currently stands, I am able to win races, sometimes easily - I'm not sure how I feel about this as it seems a little odd after so many losses, but the game is definitely still fun. As I mention below, the main adversary is the track/environment. Winning is kind of ancillary to nailing a split-second manoeuvre.ORIGINAL REVIEW:GRIP is an incredibly fast-paced spiritual successor to Rollcage.It's a hugely difficult initial experience because the default difficulty setting is Hard, and it's hard to overcome the instinct instilled in you by most other futuristic or combat-oriented racing games - just hold the accelerator down. If you are having the same difficulties many have had with the game - failing to get beyond 10th place in Hard - simply slow down and don't turn so violently. A gentle touch is required, and contrary to what you might expect, it feels much more stylish to succeed in this fashion than it does to succeed with brute strength and raw speed.It's nothing like most other racing games, because it doesn't come down to racing lines and subtlety (in the fashion of more realistic racing games), but equally it doesn't rely on ekeing out a lead with raw speed, or even taking out the competition in brutal fashion (as other futuristic 'knockabout' racing games are wont to do). These elements are sort of present, and they'll help to an extent, but they're not the main challenge, and focussing on them will harm more often than it helps. The main challenge primarily comes down to the environment, where hitting a single rock in just the wrong way can completely scupper your chances of victory. In this sense, it has much more in common with old-school games like Micro Machines than it does with its contemporaries, and you'll often feel like you're piloting an RC car in first person.Unlike many of the other positive reviewers, I sucked at Rollcage and I still suck at GRIP. I struggle to place 7th on the Medium track. And it's still fun! There are so few games where you can get your♥♥♥♥♥♥handed to you, repeatedly and thoroughly, and still enjoy the experience. A game where you can accidentally flip upside down from hitting a ramp too hard just as you launch a missile - causing you to spin right into your own missile and take yourself out - is definitely a game where it's fun to lose.I also recommend Arena mode, which is a lot of fun even against bots.Multiplayer is currently limited to (correction) two-controller split-screen, so if that's all you're after you'll be disappointed. (see comment for clarification from developer on multiplayer)

Early Access Review
								Grip's got tons of potential.I've never played the Rollcage games (which I'm actually kinda disappinted about since I grew up with a PS1) but this game will still feel nostalgic if you've ever played any old school arcade racer. The cars do take some getting used to; like a lot of people have mentioned, I got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked to hell and back on my first race. A couple of rounds later, though, and I was consistently placing higher on the game's default difficulty settings. Hell, I even won one race. The battle arena mode is fun too, and it'll be a total blast if online multiplayer makes it into the game. The weapons that are already in the game feel good, the cars have a great sense of speed to them, the tracks are pretty well designed (although there's not a lot yet) and the sound design's great. I LOVE drum and bass, so the kickass soundtrack is a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome bonus.The one and only negative thing I can think of so far is the game's sheer lack of content. As of right now, there's: 1 car, 3 tracks, and 3 battle arenas (I haven't tried out the "playground" thing yet). But that's fine since the game's in early access...the devs have shown us what they plan to do and this game can only get better as they add more content and tweak what's already here. The game runs great for me; I have a 6-core AMD processor, 8 gigs of RAM, and a GTX 970 (which is still an admittedly powerful card) and so far on max settings I've never seen a single dip below 60fps. The one guy who said this game is terribly unoptimized must be running Grip on a literal toaster; for an early access game running on Unreal 4, Grip is as smooth as hot butter.Just a quick note to the devs if they ever see this: It'd be cool if cars had health meters in races; I feel like blowing up and respawning might be a little less punishing in some situations. It'd also be neat if we saw the arena mode expanded with deathmatch-style rounds or even some team gameplay. Just suggestions; don't get me wrong, the game's already a ton of fun.Final verdict: Grip's a real breath of fresh air in a racing genre currently plagued with an over-emphasis on realism. It just wants you to have fun. I suggest you buy it now before the price goes up!

Early Access Review
								This is one intense racer.Kart/combat racers remain one of my favourite, and sadly underrated, genres. This particular game lets you drive an armed jet-fueled car that can drive upside down and stick to walls and ceilings across alien planets at speeds exceeding 600km/h, all the while accompanied by the most adrenaline pumping music I've ever heard. That has to sound cool to you. It's obvious that this game is far from being finished with a very small map selection (only 1 map is actually finished, the others are in varying stages of completion) and dozens of features listed on the site not being done yet. However, the product is recieving pretty frequent updates and the price point is very reasonable.As far as gameplay goes this plays like a very fast arcade racer, with its twist being that the cars have no up or down and have no problem driving on walls and ceilings. There's not much else to be said since the game really only has the basics down, and even those aren't perfect yet, but if you're as much of a fan of these types of games as I am you can take the gamble. It's not a lot of money. If you are just regular excited I'd wait with this game, it's far from done and no-one can tell if it'll ever be good. I have faith in the developers and I really hope they can make this game as cool as they promise, but that promise is no guarantee. If were you I'd wait until this game is a little further in development at least, because at the moment it really is in rough shape, but I'd definitely keep an eye on this game because it is promising to be a really damn good one.Oh I just read that they'll be increasing the game's price gradually over time, so you could invest now and get a good deal in return. No-one know what the final price will be but I'm guessing around the 25-30 dollars, so keep that in mind. My reccomendation remains to wait a little longer and buy this game when the basics are solid, so you can both get a decent deal and have decent confidence.

Early Access Review
								I never played Rollcage, the game this one is a spiritual successor to, but the general concept seems fun and has a lot of potential to me, which is why I decided to pick it up in Early Access. I quickly lost all desire to play after a handful of races. If you're looking into this game, it likely means that you already know what the positives are of the game currently, which is just the core idea behind it (It also looks nice, for what it's worth). Because of that, I'll only be discussing the negatives and why I don't think it's worth spending money on right now for most people.The handling feels very sensitive to me. It's possible that it's just a thing that takes some time to get used to, but in a game where you need to fit your car into tight spaces and are driving down small corridors, I feel like it screwed me up a few times. Related to that, is the camera, which can shift wildly while your car flips or turns and sometimes lingers in an awkward position, making you feel the need to tilt your head just to keep up. It's unbelievably jarring, and I found myself getting completely lost in tunnels and ending up going the wrong direction by the time I got myself oriented again. The last problem that I have with the game is that it punishes you for being in the air by making landing cleanly very difficult. Very often, your car will lose control once it hits the ground again, which seems like a really poor decision to me in a game that's so arcadey and encourages you to do crazy stuff such as jumping off of ramps.The game also seems to have some optimization issues and is missing some key features for its options menu, but I don't see these as huge negatives since it is indeed an EA game.Overall, I found this game to be pretty frustrating, and I think that would be the average gamer's impression of the game if they were to play it in it's current state, which is why it's very hard to recommend at the moment. I'll definitely be keeping an eye on this game in hopes that they make some key changes to the game so that I'll want to buy it again once it officially releases.
