Early Access Review
								I'm rarely one to purchase Early Access games due to various reasons (I'm sure if you frequent Steam enough, you can put two-and-two together), but while I am very much a lover of the classic Rollcage games, it wasn't that factor alone that persuaded me to support this game.Now, this IS early access.  There are two full RACES (Yuri Industrial and Wastelands) along with a couple prototype tracks the devs give you to test out.  There are a couple ARENAS (Biodome, an XMAS Map [as of this review] and a test area) as well as a "PLAYGROUND" mode where, well, you just goof around.  There is only one car, but a good selection of paintjobs to choose from.  You're able to customize how many racers are in the match, how many laps, toggle pick-ups ON/OFF, and set Engine Speeds (think CC in Mario Kart).  Only SOME of the item pick-ups are in the game as of now, but here's where things get good:Not only are some of the developers those who have originally worked on the RC games from 1999/2000, but they're VERY active in the community and VERY willing to listen to the community's opinions.  They've got specific checklists of suggestions for the games, bugs, what-have-you on their forums, and the updates they've given the game up to now have proven that these devs aren't simply another collective of empty promises.But this is a review for the game, not of the developers, so here are my personal thoughts on how things are ->AT THIS TIME IN EARLY ACCESS<-.PROS- Wonderful Drum 'n Bass OST- Splitscreen multiplayer- Controller support- Graphically, the game is quite pretty (and I have to run it on a lower-res than most)- Driving 500+KM/h on walls, ceilings, driving loops in tunnels and cars that drive right upside-down or rightside-up.- Fast-paced combat racing shenanigans you knew and loved in RC (or hopefully will come to love if you're a newcomer).- The devs listen to feedback and work on that feedback. Hell, even the map-designers and the 3D modelers.- Arena and Playground modes give you a couple nice-to-have alternatives if you're not in the mood for just racing all the time.CONS- As of now, there is only one type of car. (More will be added.)- A limited selection of tracks. (More will be added.)- Some people may find the car handling to be difficult at first. (They're actively working out the physics.)- The collision between cars - and occasionally the environment - is pretty wonky right now.- You can't rebind your keys or controller settings (it will be implemented).- No ONLINE Multiplayer (it will be implemented after core gameplay is nailed down).But I would always recommend that you check out some videos for GRIP to see if the gameplay is your cup of tea before purchasing, keeping in mind that some footage may be outdated (from the private Alpha test) as the changes that come with the patches often come in strides. And FYI, you can refund the game as long as you've played for less than two hours courtesy of Steam's refund policy, if it rubs you in all the wrong ways.  So it's a pretty nifty way of getting a "demo" to see for yourself.

Your cars flip and tumble like crazy and your weapons are more destructive than ever. 								I had written an earlier review of Grip, but I feel the need to come back to it. There are only a couple of early access games for me personally which have been a pleasure to watch develop over the time they've been available on Steam, and Grip is one of those games.Grip is a direct descendant of the futuristic racing genre of the 90s. It is a sublime modernization of the classic Rollcage series in Unreal Engine 4. This is not necessarily a reboot of Rollcage, it has all new tracks, locations and overall lore, however the development team behind it feature people who were involved in the original games, and the gameplay could be described as a direct evolution of the original Rollcage series.If you've not experienced Rollcage before, let me try and describe it. You have a 4 wheeled vehicle which can spin 180 degrees and operate on its roof as efficiently as it does under its starting orientation. At high speeds and against challenging foes, this mechanic bursts to life. There are weapons you pick up and use throughout each race, as well as other modes which are more combat-orientated. The whole thing runs at a blisteringly brilliant 60fps and feels genuinely faster than a lot of its competition.Throughout its early access release, the team at Caged Element have rolled out updates with satisfying regularity, which is impressive for such a small collective. They have recently launched the online multiplayer mode, and although it is still early days, the mode functions very well already and shows excellent promise for the future. I should also point out the game features an absolutely superb original soundtrack of techy drum and bass and nu-skool breaks. As a drum & bass DJ myself this is a very welcome thing to hear in a modern game, and is something you don't see all that often these days.I am massively enthusiastic about futuristic racers and have bashed the hell out of them over the past 30 years. They've had a bit of a resurgence recently with games like Distance and Redout on Steam, Fast Racing on Nintendo, as well as various others. For me, Grip is the best of this bunch, and as it continues to become a better game, there's never been a better time to jump on board.
